Yeah, I call for stop DoTs before Demon Phase and only the warlock tank is still dotting. Unfortunately it sometimes happens that that DoT doesn't tick off in time before the Searing Totem ticks and the totem gets a second of aggro. We didn't find it to be a big problem, and overall I found that it was more troublesome and a bigger waste for me to have to re-drop my WoA and Mana Spring, burning the 2 GCD's plus the extra mana cost.
#604SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Skyhoof
[Totem of Living Water]
Text is changing in Patch 2.4 to base mana cost. I believe we have been getting short changed on our mana savings with this relic.

Remember this conversation?

Originally Posted by Nitrogen
Just an FYI on your calculations for [Totem of Living Water]

The -20 mana reduction comes off the base spell cost. When you have the Tidal Focus and the first T6 set bonus, the actual mana reduction is below.

Tidal Focus - Mana cost reduced by 19.
T6 Set Bonus w/ Tidal Focus - Mana cost reduced by 17.
Originally Posted by Skyhoof
Are you sure?

First, I thought Relics were applied before set bonuses. So the Tier 6 set bonus shouldn’t impact the relic.

Second, Rank 1 HW costs 23.75 mana after talents. The totem of the Maelstrom allows you to cast this for free since it reduces the cost by 24 mana. This would imply that the totem is applied after talents.
Originally Posted by Nitrogen
Ya, I just looked at the raw numbers on my toon. If I'm not wearing any T6, total mana reduction is 19. Pretty easy to verify this with anyone running Tidal Mastery... and I double checked T6 numbers, mana cost reduction is 17 when equipped.
Well, I was absolutely convinced that relics were applied before talents and gear. However, I could not understand how Nitrogen was getting his results and I didn’t have the CH relic to test for myself. Apparently this relic was not working as intended.
#605SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Skyhoof
According to World of Raids, they have removed all the Stamina on the T6 belts, boots and bracers. This is for all classes, not just shaman. Instead, it looks like the gear has both crit and spell haste now. Doing some calculations to see whether I like this change or not.

http://www.worldofraids.com/2008/ptr/24/t6/shaman.jpg
#606SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Daidalos
Originally Posted by Skyhoof
According to World of Raids, they have removed all the Stamina on the T6 belts, boots and bracers. This is for all classes, not just shaman. Instead, it looks like the gear has both crit and spell haste now. Doing some calculations to see whether I like this change or not.

http://www.worldofraids.com/2008/ptr/24/t6/shaman.jpg
While crit is only half as good as haste per percent (not per rating it takes even more for 1% crit than 1% haste) for HPS it consummes no extra mana and I always like having it for the little for extra armor it gives. If you desperarely nee the stam there are stam gems and plenty of sockets in sunwell gear. Personally I like it since it gives me the flexibility to go for whatever I want stead of forcing a balance between stats that I may or may not need.
#607SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Skyhoof
Originally Posted by Daidalos
While crit is only half as good as haste per percent (not per rating it takes even more for 1% crit than 1% haste) for HPS it consummes no extra mana and I always like having it for the little for extra armor it gives. If you desperarely nee the stam there are stam gems and plenty of sockets in sunwell gear. Personally I like it since it gives me the flexibility to go for whatever I want stead of forcing a balance between stats that I may or may not need.
The T6 belts, boots and bracers were going to be the pieces I used to get my set bonuses. My concern is that if the gear lacks any stamina, I will not be able to wear them all the time. I will have to swap in other T6 pieces on fights that require a greater number of hit points. So this change just means I will still need to buy T6 out of BT and Hyjal rather than saving DKP for Sunwell items alone.
#608SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Yekkom
Originally Posted by Skyhoof

I’ll update the Morogrim info. However, I have never seen our demon tank have a problem getting aggro if the searing totem was down. Can you explain further what problems you have observed if the Searing Totem is left down?
A few pages back there was discussion on whether a shamans fire totems aggro gets reset on a full aggro reset. I searched high and low and cannot find a definitive answer to that question. What I do know is that a druid tank with a hunters MD and his own aggro will not out aggro a searing totem at Leo's switch to human form. Leo goes and swats the totem then goes for second highest aggro, the druid tank. This leads me to believe totems aggro does not reset.

In demon form the mechanics are slightly different. Demon Leo uses only one form of damage, Chaos Blast, which is a aoe based attack. Unlike the human form he cannot kill the totem (totems are immune to aoe effects). As such what I have noticed is a loss to the dps of at least one tick and sometimes 2 while the lock pushes out searing pains until he out aggros the totem. Most of this fights dps comes from demon form so any lost time is important here.

The time loss is small so a end game guild with T6 dps may not be bothered by the searing because they know how to kill Leo quickly. Beginning guilds will need all the help they can get to beat the enrage and that tick or two maybe the difference. This fight is very easy on healers so the extra mana used to reset the totems is never a problem.
#609SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3
Edited onPatch 2.3.3		Daidalos
Originally Posted by Yekkom
A few pages back there was discussion on whether a shamans fire totems aggro gets reset on a full aggro reset. I searched high and low and cannot find a definitive answer to that question. What I do know is that a druid tank with a hunters MD and his own aggro will not out aggro a searing totem at Leo's switch to human form. Leo goes and swats the totem then goes for second highest aggro, the druid tank. This leads me to believe totems aggro does not reset.

In demon form the mechanics are slightly different. Demon Leo uses only one form of damage, Chaos Blast, which is a aoe based attack. Unlike the human form he cannot kill the totem (totems are immune to aoe effects). As such what I have noticed is a loss to the dps of at least one tick and sometimes 2 while the lock pushes out searing pains until he out aggros the totem. Most of this fights dps comes from demon form so any lost time is important here.

The time loss is small so a end game guild with T6 dps may not be bothered by the searing because they know how to kill Leo quickly. Beginning guilds will need all the help they can get to beat the enrage and that tick or two maybe the difference. This fight is very easy on healers so the extra mana used to reset the totems is never a problem.
I asked our druid MT in full t6 if he ever was out aggroed by a searing totem and he said it i wasn't a problem if he timed it right. His thinking was that the searing totem it getting initial aggro simplydue to it constantly hitting the mob so it frequently gets the first hit after an aggro reset. He said if he timed it right the mob would never go for the totem. So I think the jury is still out about totem aggro.


Also if you placed the searing along the same vector as the lock I don't see why it would be any dps loss. Its been awhile since I did the fight but I never remember any issues with it.
Last edited by Daidalos : 02/22/08 at 11:14 AM.
#610SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3
Edited onPatch 2.3.3		Yekkom
Originally Posted by Daidalos


Also if you placed the searing along the same vector as the lock I don't see why it would be any dps loss. Its been awhile since I did the fight but I never remember any issues with it.
Might be just us but we do not dps on Demon Leo till the lock has aggro. Dps early and lock gets a searing pain resist and dps dies fast. Checked the top end guilds WWS for Leo, even their locks get searing pain resisted. Will test it out tonight and see if vector works.
Last edited by Yekkom : 02/21/08 at 8:02 PM. Reason: added content
#611SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Hodor
As I posted before, I'll post it again: Totems do not lose aggro during an aggro reset.

This means, if the Searing totem has done a total of 2k damage before the aggro reset (after a whirlwind of Leotheras for example), the totem keeps its 2k aggro while all players have 0 aggro. this obviously means, that Leotheras will head for the searing totem until a tank has built up more than 2.2k aggro or the totem was destroyed.

In short: Totems ignore aggro resets. Very simple. Not complex. Easy to understand.
#612SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Raut
Originally Posted by Skyhoof
The T6 belts, boots and bracers were going to be the pieces I used to get my set bonuses. My concern is that if the gear lacks any stamina, I will not be able to wear them all the time. I will have to swap in other T6 pieces on fights that require a greater number of hit points. So this change just means I will still need to buy T6 out of BT and Hyjal rather than saving DKP for Sunwell items alone.
Doubt that. Get one off-set item and pack it with stam gems for such an encounter or use Arena pieces. You don't want to risk your T6 4p bonus.
#613SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3
Edited onPatch 2.3.3		Herker
First Post!
First, let me say I've probably read this thread about 100 times and still haven't been able to soak the wealth of awesome information in that is posted here. You have a great resource for anyone that seriously wants to make sure they are wringing the most potential from their resto shaman.

My guild is currently progressing into SSC / TK and this site has definitely given me that last extra edge to make sure I'm performing to my most potential. I will say that the equip macros alone before casting let me wring another 1-2% on my healing alone it feels like, I never even thought about that something as simple as that.

With all the wealth of information here I'm not even sure what I could add, nothing groundbreaking for sure.

The only extra tip I could add after re-reading the awesome posts here that I didn't see was a trick we learned while fighting Netherspit on accident (I'm sure its pretty widespread knowledge, but didn't see it in the original post with regards to things resto shaman can do in specific encounters).

Netherspite:
From what I've seen, during banish phase most guilds leave a tank in and the rest of the people gather underneath NS or behind her and bandage / pot, whatever. However, If you leave a searing totem in front of NS and call no DOTS about 15sec prior to the banish, the searing totem will hold 100% of the NS's aggro and will not take AOE damage from NS. This allows the whole raid (including tank) to bandage and make fun of the gnomes in raid. Make sure the tank is ready to pickup aggro upon the completion of banish.

Again this isn't groundbreaking and NS isn't really a hard fight once you get the communication down, just my 2 copper on adding a bit of value to a site that has provided so much to me.

Thanks again from the silent majority for your efforts here on this site.

We just brought mags down as we are transitioning a bit backwards from most guild through the content i guess...FYI earthbind helps alot when the infernals are running around, however earthbind if dropped before the encounter starts, will start it as it counts as an aoe...doh...bad shammy...bad.

If you're ever in the neighborhood on Hellscream and need a healer or a crappy alt prot warrior let me know.
Last edited by Herker : 02/22/08 at 2:05 PM.

This means, if the Searing totem has done a total of 2k damage before the aggro reset (after a whirlwind of Leotheras for example), the totem keeps its 2k aggro while all players have 0 aggro. this obviously means, that Leotheras will head for the searing totem until a tank has built up more than 2.2k aggro or the totem was destroyed.

In short: Totems ignore aggro resets. Very simple. Not complex. Easy to understand.

#616SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3vikinghelmet
2.4 Totem changes?
Hi.

First I wanted to thank everyone who contributes to this thread. I started getting rushed into my guild because they needed a Restoration Shaman and this thread really helped me get up to speed with what I was supposed to be doing.

I also read the Enhancement thread and they have been talking about the new changes to Totems in 2.4 in which a macro is added which will allow you to selectively destroy totems (and get mana back as if you were casting Totemic Recall). I thought I would mention it since not everyone necessarily reads the other threads and I hadn't seen it mentioned here.

-VikingHelmet

#618SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Hodor
Originally Posted by Daidalos

Sorry if I came across a little harsh.

If I read your post correctly, the statement of your tank in no way questions the theory of totems not being affected by an aggro reset. I am guessing that he simply use a high aggro attack in order to out aggro the totem instantly. If he only uses a normal attack, then it is quite possible the totem will still have aggro if it has been up for a significant amount of time before the aggro reset.

So far I have not seem anything happen that has seriously challenged my theory that totems are not affected by aggro resets.

Oh and btw, the new Tier 6 pieces now have some Stamina again.

#620SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3
Edited onPatch 2.3.3		Kremlin
First and foremost, I would like to apologize for taking this discussion in a new direction but I recently had an interesting thought with regard to Water Shield. Limited testing performed in game of this ability seems to suggest as soon as Water Shield is cast, 50 mana is instantly restored to the caster; with an additional 50 restored every 5 seconds thereafter. Now, suppose this testing is true and one refreshes Water Shield every time the global cooldown has "cooled down". In a lag free environment, it would be possible to restore 150 mana in the the 5 second period instead of 50 with 0.5 seconds to spare.

1.5 * 3 = 4,5
3 * 50 = 150

Obviously, this relies on the instant tic theory of Water Shield to be true which very well may be false. However, if true, it could prove quite useful in situations where little healing is required and a Shaman may comfortably sit in the GCD for a few seconds to regain some extra mana. As Water Shield costs nothing, a Shaman could do this and still remain outside the 5 second rule.

EDIT: Further testing has proven this theory wrong and therefore this post is rendered useless. Apologies for taking up space.
Last edited by Kremlin : 02/23/08 at 9:00 AM.
#621SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3
Edited onPatch 2.3.3		Arfea
Originally Posted by Shinwei
Does anyone have any experience with the [Mystical Skyfire Diamond] and the Sunwell encounters on the PTR? As we know there have been some changes made to the MSD on the PTR, and I would like to know if anyone has raided Sunwell there and could share their experience with the meta.

As it stands currently I use the MSD in my T6 helm, and I recently picked up a 2nd Tier 6 Helm token and I'm debating whether or not I should buy another Resto helm to put in an IED or just get an Elemental helm for fun. In my experiences through Black Temple I have come to the conclusion that the MSD is by far the better gem for all encounters but the Illidari Council. This is because we have everything on farm status now and bosses drop a lot faster than I can run OOM with my mana regen from elsewhere.

I suspect that when learning new bosses more mana regen is going to be very important, but I would still like to know how the MSD performs in Sunwell. Are there any periods of extreme burst raid or tank damage? Are any of the bosses "skinny" enough for Chain Heal to bounce from tank to melee (in which case it may be a good idea to assign a Resto Shaman to heal the tank)? Information like this would be greatly appreciated.
I have some experience with this meta on the ptr. The actual haste number eludes me, but I'll edit this post once I can log the PTR (if anyone remembers the exact number, feel free Edit:320).


For the record, the change is from Next spell cast is cast in half time (consumes the charge) to your spells cast faster (not consumed and 4(?) second charge). It's therefore possible to cast two chain healswith one skyfire proc, although currently with PTR lag it can be a bit tricky. I *think* my chain heal went from 2.4 sec>2.1, again I can't remember for sure and I will omit any erronous figures once I can log ptr again.

I've only tried the first two bosses. At least on kaelcgos, the extra haste can be really nice. The boss(es) can do some nasty chain combo specials that can leave multiple people very low on health, and this is where fast multi-target heals are useful.

Second boss I only tried once, is less raid damage orientated and more hitting-your-tank-extremely-hard orientated and I would guess with the spam healing need that earthstorm diamond would be more suited as it appears to be mana intensive.

Both bosses are huge so there is very little chain healing bouncing off the tank. I think that if people get their spacing right and don't do anything stupid to get alot of damage, that you generally won't need, skyfires proc for raidwide damage. Kalecgos and the demon can have significant burst (think morogrim on your first attempts), and Brut has insane burst, so choose what you prefer.

My own decision at this time is to change to ISD and put MSD in a hasted (considering the timer on its charge) set such as Skyhoof suggested; [Shroud of Chieftain Ner'zhul] would be really nice for it. ISD is a surefire safe choice for me as additional mana is always added to your pool during your fight to be used at a later stage, whilst the MSD can proc at odd and uneeded times and is on a short timer.

Hope this helped.
Last edited by Arfea : 02/23/08 at 9:36 AM. Reason: broken item link
#622SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3savag
24/0/37 spec
i havent looked at all the pages on here but have you looked into 24/0/37 as a raiding spec? it gives 34.6 more mp5 with 455 int and goes up to 43.52 more mp5 with AI and Kings buffs
its linked below

WorldofWarcraft.com -> Info -> Classes -> Shaman -> Talent Calculator

and yes no improved healing wave ya never use those things in a raid

i never run outa mana with this spec and ya dont have earth sheild which does help alot but its sorta hard to spam those in a raid which using prayer of mending would be better suited for which is a less cost in mana and jumps around.

i've been using this spec alot and i've usually rocked with it but i've only been up to TK and SSC it helps for those long fights which if that Spriest doesnt show up or if ya dont wanna just burn through mana pots i've servived a whole mag fight with using 1 mana pot and that was cause i got cought in convlagaration and died and ankhed back up

and dont just find a bunch of flaws with it. yes you do reduce alot of + healing but it helps alot with your mp5.

just putting this out there if ya ever wanna try saying something about it
#623SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Mooncrow
You would have to look at some of the older threads for a full discussion on the Elemental/Resto hybrid builds, but I'll sum it up: basically spending 16 points for ~48 mp5 just isn't worth it for a shaman who primarily heals. If you're often called to help dps a little, then the builds become closer, but the sacrifice of flexibility and +heal still makes it a toss up.

#625SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Skyhoof
Originally Posted by Herker
Netherspite:
From what I've seen, during banish phase most guilds leave a tank in and the rest of the people gather underneath NS or behind her and bandage / pot, whatever. However, If you leave a searing totem in front of NS and call no DOTS about 15sec prior to the banish, the searing totem will hold 100% of the NS's aggro and will not take AOE damage from NS. This allows the whole raid (including tank) to bandage and make fun of the gnomes in raid. Make sure the tank is ready to pickup aggro upon the completion of banish.

Again this isn't groundbreaking and NS isn't really a hard fight once you get the communication down, just my 2 copper on adding a bit of value to a site that has provided so much to me.
We did a Kara badge run this weekend and gave this strategy a try. The strategy will work as long as no one attacks Netherspite during the banish phase. If they don't stop their attack, they will quickly out-aggro the Searing Totem. So if your guild's normal strategy is to do no DPS while a tank stands in front of NS, a searing totem would be a great improvement.

However, we like to hit things in my guild. Therefore, for us, it's better to continue DPS during the banish and run through NS when he does the breath.

i've been using this spec alot and i've usually rocked with it but i've only been up to TK and SSC it helps for those long fights which if that Spriest doesnt show up or if ya dont wanna just burn through mana pots i've servived a whole mag fight with using 1 mana pot and that was cause i got cought in convlagaration and died and ankhed back up

just putting this out there if ya ever wanna try saying something about it

You lose Natures Blessing which now means your Rank 5 Chains heals hit at a Rank 4 level. This at a cost of 100 or so extra mana per heal. You gained 43 mana/5 but lost the 200/5 if you down ranked your chains. You also lose the extra threat your ES does for the tank which ups his aggro allowing DPS to work harder. The ES also helps on spikes as a quasi hot.
#627SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3galzohar
NS resets aggro when he unbanishes, so how much dps your raid did during banish phase is meaningless, although if totems ignore aggro resets it should keep the aggro.

"Evidence" for him to not reset aggro at the start of the banish phase:
1. If you notice he still melees (or tries to melee if out of range) the highest person on threat during banish phase. You will often not notice that because he moves rediculessly slow and that person will usually be the ranged DPSer that was in the blue beam. If the ranged DPSer will stand in melee when he's highest on threat, netherspite can and will kill him between netherbreaths.
2. It's always that person that didn't stop dps/DoTs that gets aggro when he unbanishes, not a person that I generally trust to have good dps.

Next kara pug I run I'm definitely trying a searing totem.
#628SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3
Edited onPatch 2.3.3		Skyhoof
Originally Posted by galzohar
NS resets aggro when he unbanishes, so how much dps your raid did during banish phase is meaningless, although if totems ignore aggro resets it should keep the aggro.
The Searing Totem appears to be the one object in the game not affected by aggro resets. We do not know whether the effect is intended or a bug that has existed since the creation of the game. After the banish phase ends, Netherspite will remain aggroed on the Searing Totem, giving your tank time to pick him up before the portals reappear.

Originally Posted by galzohar
"Evidence" for him to not reset aggro at the start of the banish phase:
1. If you notice he still melees (or tries to melee if out of range) the highest person on threat during banish phase. You will often not notice that because he moves rediculessly slow and that person will usually be the ranged DPSer that was in the blue beam. If the ranged DPSer will stand in melee when he's highest on threat, netherspite can and will kill him between netherbreaths.
2. It's always that person that didn't stop dps/DoTs that gets aggro when he unbanishes, not a person that I generally trust to have good dps.

Next kara pug I run I'm definitely trying a searing totem.
There is evidence that the start of the banish phase is not a complete aggro wipe. I believe anyone who was standing in a beam has their aggro reset. However, it would be very easy for the person who took the blue beam to get to the top of the list. They will still have the damage buff for 10 seconds.

EDIT: I realized that I didn't include my favorite shaman trick with Netherspite.

Healing Stream: Drop at the end of the portal phase while you still have the +healing buff from the green beam.

I seem to recall ticks for more than +500 healing.
Last edited by Skyhoof : 02/25/08 at 3:11 PM.
#629SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3galzohar
I suppose it could use more testing but coming out of banish seems to behave just like other aggro reseting bosses - same kind of bad/good tanks fail/succeed to pick it up and same kind of bad/good players fail/succeed in stopping dps right as he comes out that do the same on this fight. But if you're saying it is some kind of a partial reset then this is no evidence and more testing is needed - however I highly doubt that. Could be easily verified with one of the tanks going AFK at the start and trying to pick up the boss as he comes out of the banish, with everyone going all out for the whole time until ~10 seconds before banish ends (stopping DoTS ~20s before).
#630SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Skyhoof

I suppose it could use more testing but coming out of banish seems to behave just like other aggro reseting bosses - same kind of bad/good tanks fail/succeed to pick it up and same kind of bad/good players fail/succeed in stopping dps right as he comes out that do the same on this fight. But if you're saying it is some kind of a partial reset then this is no evidence and more testing is needed - however I highly doubt that. Could be easily verified with one of the tanks going AFK at the start and trying to pick up the boss as he comes out of the banish, with everyone going all out for the whole time until ~10 seconds before banish ends (stopping DoTS ~20s before).

No, I was talking about the start of the banish phase being some sort of partial aggro reset. The end of banish is a complete aggro wipe (except for Searing Totem).
#631SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Monsoone
I think spell haste has additional utility for healers beyond just HPM considerations. In most situations, I am not spamming heal spells; I am casting when someone is hurt. In these situations, the best possible outcome would be for the heal to land now, before they get hit again and possibly killed. Of course we've all been in situations where we are spamming heals on a tank and cancelling, but as a shaman, when I'm healing in a raid most of the time my job is on the raid and healing when its needed.

The valuation of spell haste should include this utility value beyond just "what the math says". Of course, this is a completely subjective calculation that would be difficult/impossible to quantify, but just because its not quantifiable doesn't mean its valueless. To sum up, healing is outcome based, and having spell haste will keep someone alive in situations that not having it would result in their death, beyond simple consideration of how much extra healing you will do over time.
#632SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Grash
Hello, Pro Resto shamans

I have one question. Please, help me.

I've noticed that TK/SSC gear have less stamina than T4 related gear. I mean it is improving your heals but reducing your health. Thus, i want to know how many unbuffed hp (in common) must have shaman to survive in TK/SSC? (atm i have ~7500hp and i am afraid that if i will start taking TK/SSC gear, i will drop my hp on very low level)
#633SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3TheSorcerer
Originally Posted by Monsoone
I think spell haste has additional utility for healers beyond just HPM considerations. In most situations, I am not spamming heal spells; I am casting when someone is hurt. In these situations, the best possible outcome would be for the heal to land now, before they get hit again and possibly killed. Of course we've all been in situations where we are spamming heals on a tank and cancelling, but as a shaman, when I'm healing in a raid most of the time my job is on the raid and healing when its needed.

The valuation of spell haste should include this utility value beyond just "what the math says". Of course, this is a completely subjective calculation that would be difficult/impossible to quantify, but just because its not quantifiable doesn't mean its valueless. To sum up, healing is outcome based, and having spell haste will keep someone alive in situations that not having it would result in their death, beyond simple consideration of how much extra healing you will do over time.
This benefit is really marginal. Most of the time if you start healing a person when he will not survive long enough for a 2.5 second cast, you, as a healer, really did something wrong. A really important lesson to learn while working to become a good healer is to be able to recognize who *will* become damage.

Eg. on Illidari Council you will recognize someone getting hit by the rogue before most of the damage is dealt by the deadly poison debuff. Or you can see who will be hit by the priests Holy Fire variant due to the fact the priest will target him while casting the spell. It is stuff like this, that you'll need to recognize and learn to emphasize. Debuffs and Aggro will tell you alot about who will soon be dealt damage. Beeing able to see that helps you alot more than 0.2 seconds casttime off of your chainheal.

That said of course spellhaste will make you cast your spells faster and might safe one or two lifes, however, it will hardly help if your reaction time is worse than that of loaded truck at full speed.

My personal opinion is you should not gear for spellhaste because your heals will land a few parts of a second earlier. I'd only gear for haste on fights where I need to max my heal throughput. However, some of the spellhaste gear you can get might even be worth considering on a not "maxed healoutput"-fight, eg the heroic badges girdle or the BT trash rings. They'd be at least allright without the spellhaste, but it's a nice bonus and might safe that person once in a while.
#634SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3• Vema
Originally Posted by Grash
I've noticed that TK/SSC gear have less stamina than T4 related gear. I mean it is improving your heals but reducing your health. Thus, i want to know how many unbuffed hp (in common) must have shaman to survive in TK/SSC? (atm i have ~7500hp and i am afraid that if i will start taking TK/SSC gear, i will drop my hp on very low level)
7500 Unbuffed HP is reasonable for most fights. 8000 unbuffed is enough to cover you for just about anything. For specific fights that your want a higher HP pool you can pick up a few pvp items like a s3 neck and chest, gem/enchant them for stamina and you can swap on 1-2k more life.
#635SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3amroberts59
The only fights in TK/SSC you actually need a decent amount of health are Tidewalker and Solarian. For both i'd say you need anywhere from 8k-10k *buffed* HP. Moreso on the higher end of that range though.
#636SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Grash
Originally Posted by Vema
7500 Unbuffed HP is reasonable for most fights. 8000 unbuffed is enough to cover you for just about anything. For specific fights that your want a higher HP pool you can pick up a few pvp items like a s3 neck and chest, gem/enchant them for stamina and you can swap on 1-2k more life.
Yes, but the problem is not in my gear atm. The problem is in gear from SSC/TK which improving healing and reduces stamina. For example, [Worldstorm Gauntlets] from Solarian and [Cyclone Gloves] from T4. As you can see, Worldstorm Gauntlents have less stamina than Cyclone Gloves. This means -70 hp to me only from gloves. I know that i can easily set gauntlents with stamina gem and even doing this gauntlents would be improvement for me. But not all T5 related gear have gem slots and i am in doubt about such "improvement" (stamina instead of healing/mp5 gem). Is 7k hp unbuffed would be good for TK/SSC encounters?
#637SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Skyhoof
First, I have to question if you actually read the main post.

4. How much +healing and mp5 should I have?

Tier 5
Health: 7500-8200
Mana: 9000-10,000
Mp5: 150-200
Healing: 1900-2100
Originally Posted by Grash
Is 7k hp unbuffed would be good for TK/SSC encounters?
It’s not ideal. However, it’s fairly easy for a shaman to get 7.5k health unbuffed.

Your shield currently has no enchant so if you are concerned about hp put +18 stamina on it.
Your boots currently have the Vitality enchant. Use Boar’s speed with its +9 stamina and run speed boost.

Those changes alone would increase your health by 270.

Also, you have a very nice neck and ring. Unfortunately, one reason they are so good for healing is that they lack stamina. There are many alternatives available with stamina. Use them on encounters where you need more hit points.

And please read the section on gem choices. Some of your choices make my eyes water.
#638SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Mistaya
If you have 10k raid buffed HP you are set for every encounter in the game. It's that simple. Personally I wear my S3 chest when I need stamina and it usually pushes me over the mark.

Originally Posted by Monsoone
To sum up, healing is outcome based, and having spell haste will keep someone alive in situations that not having it would result in their death, beyond simple consideration of how much extra healing you will do over time.
I've been raiding as a T4 geared shaman in a T6 guild for some weeks and I can't stress how valuable my MSD is to my healing. Mana is cheap and easy to come by between Water shield, shadow priests, and pots, but no amount of mana is going to keep my group up on Gurtogg when I'm spamming Chain heal 5 and it's only hitting for 3k on the first bump. I rely on those procs (and emergency NS's) to be able to do my job in a place I'm undergeared for. That half-casted Chain heal makes up for the lack of healing on the 5 before it, you know?

I don't really understand the difficulty in timing people mention. I chain cast- there's rarely a GCD I am not using, and I'm very confident at predicting roughly when my MSD will proc. The first proc is 1-4 casts (roughly) and usually a waste. After that it's always up right when I'm falling behind on raid healing, and I've kept many many raid members alive solely because of it. Hell even tank healing, having 2 back to back HW's land that fast is something that saves raids.

Of course there are wasted procs, and it isn't saving a raid every fight. It does so enough however that I've honestly never considered a helm with no meta because it's such an important proc to my playstyle.
#639SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3
Edited onPatch 2.3.3		Vistol
Originally Posted by Monsoone
I think spell haste has additional utility for healers beyond just HPM considerations. In most situations, I am not spamming heal spells; I am casting when someone is hurt. In these situations, the best possible outcome would be for the heal to land now, before they get hit again and possibly killed. Of course we've all been in situations where we are spamming heals on a tank and cancelling, but as a shaman, when I'm healing in a raid most of the time my job is on the raid and healing when its needed.

The valuation of spell haste should include this utility value beyond just "what the math says". Of course, this is a completely subjective calculation that would be difficult/impossible to quantify, but just because its not quantifiable doesn't mean its valueless. To sum up, healing is outcome based, and having spell haste will keep someone alive in situations that not having it would result in their death, beyond simple consideration of how much extra healing you will do over time.
I think a portion of the value could be calculated as spirit based regen as haste puts you back outside the five second rule (5SR) sooner. This will only improve come 2.4 when haste lowers the global cool down (GCD), but you can approximate a effect haste has on regen.

Now, no matter what this is going to be a very small number as most of us spend the majority of our time inside the 5SR. Under current conditions assume you end every cast sequence with a chain heal, determine the number of times you enter the 5SR multiply that by the cast time reduction from haste and then figure out the extra regen.

Now granted this will only be the extreme upper end value of this regen, but one you can figure out none the less. Now this number is still going to be small and in fact on most fights if this resulted in significant regen, you're probably doing something wrong.

Please note I'm not saying staking spirit and haste is a good idea, but they are somewhat complementary.
Last edited by Vistol : 02/27/08 at 5:14 PM. Reason: fixed an error in my post

#641SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Vanquish
Ok, a subject that was touched on in this thread was spell crit. Seeing as though our main spell used has an individual chance to crit, what is the chance per each cast of CH for the initial heal, or subsequent jumps to crit?

My basic thinking, is by stacking a bit more spell crit that i can throught crit's improve the effectiveness of chain heal's subsequent jumps, outside of using T2 ... or a challenge for you number crunchers, at what point will spell crit provide an equal benefit to 3pce T2?

I'm thinking mainly for heavy dmg fights such as BB, RoS 3 and Naj where the sheer amount of raid dmg negates the issue of overheal.
#642SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3vorda
where the sheer amount of raid dmg negates the issue of overheal.
That still has one of the problems some (or most, no idea) paladins have with gearing/gemming for crit. Is it wise to rely on a dice roll to keep people alive? Because if your heal doesnt crit and they are in no danger of dying, having it crit wont change that fact. On the other side, when they do need HP quickly, crit is still unreliable and they might still die.

I'd recommend strolling over to the Healadin topic to read some thoughts on the pure healing effectiveness of spell crit rating. (while not directly aplied to Chain heal, the same goes there. 3pc t2 is a reliable bonus you know you will have, much like +heal)

#651SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3
Edited onPatch 2.3.3		Fodla
Is +6mp5 better than +6stats for chest:
Consider T5+ raid buffed stats.
Approx.
+Heal - 2200
MP5 whilst casting 300
Spell crit - 10% (not including 5% from talents)
Mana - 13000

Without a shadow priest you'd be able to spam CH5 for approx 92s before going OOM.(with totem of living water)

6mp5 would not change that as you'd only gain 110 mana back in that time. Not enough for another CH5 cast.

Add 6.6 intellect (BoK)
Spell crit 10.08 %
+Heal 2202.2
Mana 13099

You'd still last 92s, however, the HPM would increase by 0.01 and approx 1hps better. (this with a 100/50/10 hit split)Doesn't sound alot, but for me, i don't miss the mp5 and would rather have the extra stats.

Would this improve over a 10 minute fight? The extra heal and crit directly affects the amount of healing done and if you get a shadow priest there is not even a need to worry about that mp5 loss.

Anyway, i'm just putting it out there that +6 stats is a raid viable enchant.
Thoughts please.

(disclaimer: spreadsheet calculations for rank spamming which i could write out if really needed. fairly sure it's about right though)
Last edited by Fodla : 02/28/08 at 11:36 AM.

There's a phrase i'm fond of, 'Over Engineering' Based on your current gear levels neither 6mp5 or 6 stats would make a huge difference to your performance. So this, in my opinion, is more of a personal choice. Benefits of 6 stats, obviously sta and int, none of the other stats are relevant.

So the choice is between 60 HP and 90 mana and + 2 heals or 6 mp5. Worst case scenario you get put in a tank grp, or have no SP you'd benefit from the MP5 more. You will never be sure of a crit with anything less than 100% but you can get above 90% at 55% crit. Assuming each jump has a chance to proc.
Last edited by Vistol : 02/28/08 at 2:46 PM. Reason: me speel good
#655SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Vistol
Originally Posted by Fodla
Is +6mp5 better than +6stats for chest:

Anyway, i'm just putting it out there that +6 stats is a raid viable enchant.
Thoughts please.

(disclaimer: spreadsheet calculations for rank spamming which i could write out if really needed. fairly sure it's about right though)

Short answer no, i don't think it's even close.

You are using a metric to compare the two that in no way represents actual combat. You are determining the value of the stats under a very specific set of conditions, i.e. maximizing the total amount healed by spamming rank 5 chain heal until oom. Under these conditions mp5 has almost no value and spell crit offers huge returns.

Now i believe that most people would agree that mp5 > crit, under most normal circumstances. However, the fact is stat weights are dynamic depending on the encounter, and your role in it. Shorter encounters favor haste and int, where as longer fights favor mp5 (healing is always good).

While it is possible conditions exsist where +6 stats is better i would say the majority of the time 6mp5 is much better, but hey I'm all for having multiple sets of gear and switching out pieces depending on the fight.

Just my 2 coppers.
#656SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3galzohar
Your calculations also assume the fight is over when you go oom, on top of the other issues they have that had already been mentioned in the above posts.

Under these conditions mp5 has almost no value and spell crit offers huge returns.

Now i believe that most people would agree that mp5 > crit, under most normal circumstances. However, the fact is stat weights are dynamic depending on the encounter, and your role in it. Shorter encounters favor haste and int, where as longer fights favor mp5 (healing is always good).

Whilst i'd say it is specific, this also scales if you just 'up' the mp5 to cater for a 10 minute fight. i.e. it's something like 882mp5 needed to spam CH5 for 10 minutes. The benefit is actually greater in that instance for +6stats over mp5 on HPS, the difference being something like being able to heal for an extra 38 seconds, but still not actually putting out any more healing in total over those 38s.
Again, it's not 'real' world per se, but would kind of mirrors having a Shadow Priest, chugging mana pots etc.

In a looong fight, the mp5 may edge it, but even in a 10 minute fight, you'd only regain 720 mana.
Whilst on a point for point basis, mp5 > crit, i think once you get to a certain point, then the extra crit gained will increase the healing output over the course of the fight. Most fights are between 3 and 7 minutes so MP5 is wasted above a certain threshold (which would be a nice calculation to do)

Try it and see is all i can say

#660SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Vanquish
Originally Posted by Vistol
P of at least one jump criting = 1-(1-spell crit)^3 .... assuming 3 jumps and that each is a discreet event (which to be honest i don't know for sure).

You will never be sure of a crit with anything less than 100% but you can get above 90% at 55% crit. Assuming each jump has a chance to proc.

That seems too high, remember each jump has a chance to proc, yet the crit value can only realistically be applied to the initial cast. By that i mean in simplistic terms that 100% crit/ 3 jumps would be an average of 34% crit from stats to achieve one crit per cast. (i am far from a maths genius, so forgive my over simplification)

How does crit scale in terms of HPS? and is it a viable stat to be focusing on when mp5 is at an optimum level?

I'm currently trying to build in as much crit as possibly, while retaining as much mp5/heals as possible. This will affect gear choices quite dramatically taking into account gem sockets, and balancing of Mp5.

I guess ideally i'd like someone to calculate a weight for crit as a stat in terms of how it increases hps on average, and how much crit will equal a certain increase in hps over time. (only in relation to chain heal)

I know alot is down to personal taste, but coming from a dps background pre tbc, it seems spell crit is underrated for shaman, when we have the ideal spell to take advantage of the stat.
#661SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3
Edited onPatch 2.3.3		Vistol
Originally Posted by Vanquish
That seems too high, remember each jump has a chance to proc, yet the crit value can only realistically be applied to the initial cast. By that i mean in simplistic terms that 100% crit/ 3 jumps would be an average of 34% crit from stats to achieve one crit per cast. (i am far from a maths genius, so forgive my over simplification)
.
.
That is the correct value and formula. What i did was figure out the % chance of 0 crits (call that X)and did 100%-X. Yes each jump can crit, but they can crit one, two, all three at the same time, or even none at all; as they are all independent events. That is if the first bounce cirts (or doesn't) it has no impact on if the next jumps do or do not.

The way you describe the events would have to be linked, and if the first bounce crit the others would be locked out, also if it didn't cirt the odds of the next 2 jumps criting would have to go up.

Edits below

The biggest issue with gearing for crit when healing is what it should do and what it does do can be two drastically different things. Given the small number of spells you cast to between incoming damage to the raid, which could kill targets for which you are responsible, the variance in outcomes will be drastic. The first law of statistics is "unlikely events can and must occur" therefore you will end up with large peeks and valleys in the number of crits per min. So depending on chain heal crit spam to allow you a certain amount HPS is a shaky proposition.

If we assume a "normal distribution" this means that 75% of your cast sequences will be within three standard deviations, this also means that 12.5% of your sequences will significantly under preform. So by depending on crit to get a certain amount of HPS means about 1 out of 10 times you need to get some healing done before your targets die you will not be up to your standard abilities (tell that to your raid leader).

At the end of the day while crit will increase your average HPS, counting on it to do so when you really need it to will cause you to fail at your responsibilities from time to time.
Last edited by Vistol : 02/28/08 at 10:15 PM. Reason: some more thoughts on spell crit
#662SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Vanquish
Yes, i understand your concerns on spell crit. Perhaps I need to explain My thinking a bit better. This is currently how i view healing stats in order of importance.

1)+ Heals
2)Mp5
3)Spell Crit
4)Sta
5)Int
6)Haste

Now in my opinion, once heals and MP5 are at a satisfactory level I will look to build in spell crit. These two stats seem to sort themselves through normal gear progression.

The problem is, that assuming the above are at a workable level, will I be reducing my effectivness by choosing to increase crit or gaining a valuable 'bonus' to an already well balanced set of stats?

This is why i was hoping for some form of Weighted value on spell crit in relation to chain heal, as I personally feel there is potential for spell crit as an alternative to maxing +heals.

I haven't had much experience with haste, although I have to admit I do like the sound of building haste into a gear set, but my concerns are the impact on regen with no SP.
#663SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Mistaya
About chain heal and spell crit-

While the initial target of chain heal critting is likely to overheal, in a situation where you are healing say a pack of melee, having the second and third jump of chain heal crit is much less likely to overheal since the jumps heal for much less and all targets are taking roughly equal damage. I think spellcrit is useful in helping to even out the healing done by the chain heal jumps over the course of a fight.
#664SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Vistol
Ok, now i understand what you are getting at. Let me help you make your case somewhat.

Your view is that all 6 stats related healing have diminishing marginal utility (i.e. each point offers less value than the point before it) and once you reach say 2400 +heals and 350 mp5 self buffed (or less with an SP) the marginal utility gained from spell crit far out weighs the benefit of putting points in either of the other two.

Now i will agree that you can have enough mp5, almost anytime you end a fight with mana you can say you had to much mp5. However i don't know if healing behaves like that, it could offer liner returns, or due to down ranking +healing may have increasing marginal utility, or even look like a wave.

So this becomes the question, does additional +healing stop being less beneficial than additional crit? And if so at what point?

I'm inclined to think +healings slope coefficient on its utility curve is always >=1, meaning each point of healing is at least as good as the point before it. But i don't know if i could ever prove it.
#665SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3
Edited onPatch 2.3.3		yaya@EU-hyjal
Originally Posted by Vanquish


This is why i was hoping for some form of Weighted value on spell crit in relation to chain heal, as I personally feel there is potential for spell crit as an alternative to maxing +heals.
Spell crit can be directly compared to spell haste because they both increase HPS (Healing Per Second).

1% spell haste increases your HPS by 1% and 1% crit increases HPS by 0.5%. It means 1% haste is worth 2% crit. However you need 15.7 haste rating to get 1% haste and 22.1 crit rating for 1% spell crit. So 15.7 haste is worth 44.2 crit.

1 haste rating is worth 2.81 spell crit rating (not considering ancestral fortitude). Spell haste is much more valuable than spell crit. (edit: more valuable for HPS !)
Last edited by yaya@EU-hyjal : 02/29/08 at 10:19 AM.
#666SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3vorda
Originally Posted by yaya@EU-hyjal
Spell crit can be directly compared to spell haste because they both increase HPS (Healing Per Second).

1% spell haste increases your HPS by 1% and 1% crit increases HPS by 0.5%. It means 1% haste is worth 2% crit. However you need 15.7 haste rating to get 1% haste and 22.1 crit rating for 1% spell crit. So 15.7 haste is worth 44.2 crit.

1 haste rating is worth 2.81 spell crit rating (not considering ancestral fortitude). Spell haste is much more valuable than spell crit.
While I agree that haste is much much more valuable then crit, you did fail to mention that the increased HPS from crit also comes at an increase HPM. (which is not the case for haste)

Anyway, again, I fully agree that the way to increase HPS is haste and the way to increase HPS and HPM is +heal.
#667SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3
Edited onPatch 2.3.3		yaya@EU-hyjal
Originally Posted by vorda

you did fail to mention that the increased HPS from crit also comes at an increase HPM. (which is not the case for haste)
You are right, 1% spell crit increases HPM by 0.5% in addition to increasing HPS. Let's estimate roughly the impact of this increase in HPM.

By looking at the numbers in the first post, let's consider a chain heal that heals for 5156 for 513 mana. That makes a HPM of 10.05. With the benefit of 1% crit the HPM becomes 10.1. This increase in HPM is equivalent to a 3 mana reduction (because 5156/510 = 10.1). It is therefore equivalent to (roughly) 6 mp5.

Oh my... I thought the increase in HPM was neglictible but apparently it is not the case...

In conclusion 10 spell crit rating is equivalent to 3,5 haste rating plus 2,7 mp5 (when chain-casting). Seems like a good stat after all... Any other opinion ?
Last edited by yaya@EU-hyjal : 02/29/08 at 2:50 PM.
#668SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Vanquish
Originally Posted by yaya@EU-hyjal
Spell crit can be directly compared to spell haste because they both increase HPS (Healing Per Second).

1% spell haste increases your HPS by 1% and 1% crit increases HPS by 0.5%. It means 1% haste is worth 2% crit. However you need 15.7 haste rating to get 1% haste and 22.1 crit rating for 1% spell crit. So 15.7 haste is worth 44.2 crit.

1 haste rating is worth 2.81 spell crit rating (not considering ancestral fortitude). Spell haste is much more valuable than spell crit.
Would these figures still be the case for chain heal though?

Haste offers no improvement to the subsequent jumps, and it seems using the figures you provided(again over simplified) if indeed 1% crit gives a .5% increase in HPS, then the multiplier affect of the 3 jumps of chain heal would apply an average hps increase from chain heal of 1.5%.

If this is correct then chain heal and spell crit would be more viable in certain circumstances.

One thing i haven't factored in is the effect on GCD, although our totems now have a base GCD of 1sec, with our only other instant cast spells being purge (dispells usually handled by totems), the benefit of reducing GCD is negligable. (at the lower levels of haste)
#669SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Squish
Ehrm, no, as stated a rough estimate of 1%crit is to increase your HPS by 0.5%. This means that you go from casting 1000+500+250 chainheals to 1005+502.5+251.25 ones, or from 1750 total to 1758.75 ones on avarage, which surprise surprise is a 0.5% increase.

Please note that the the linked heal is not 50% of the actual healing done on the previous target, in that case crit would be way nicer, but 50% of what a non-critted heal would have healed for.

Hast as stated does indeed not at all affect what the following targets are healed for, instead it simply allows you to cast %haste more spells in the same amount of time, ie a straight haste->HPS conversion. Although at the cost of increased MPS, a burden crit does not share with haste.
#670SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3vorda
Originally Posted by yaya@EU-hyjal
You are right, 1% spell crit increases HPM by 0.5% in addition to increasing HPS. Let's estimate roughly the impact of this increase in HPM.

By looking at the numbers in the first post, let's consider a chain heal that heals for 5156 for 513 mana. That makes a HPM of 10.05. With the benefit of 1% crit the HPM becomes 10.1. This increase in HPM is equivalent to a 3 mana reduction (because 5156/510 = 10.1). It is therefore equivalent to (roughly) 6 mp5.

Oh my... I thought the increase in HPM was neglictible but apparently it is not the case...

In conclusion 10 spell crit rating is equivalent to 3,5 haste rating plus 2,7 mp5. Seems like a good stat after all... Any other opinion ?
One thing worth noting is that crit is unreliable and because of that, you cant either count on it happening, or count on it not overhealing.
#671SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Daidalos
Originally Posted by Vanquish
Would these figures still be the case for chain heal though?

Haste offers no improvement to the subsequent jumps, and it seems using the figures you provided(again over simplified) if indeed 1% crit gives a .5% increase in HPS, then the multiplier affect of the 3 jumps of chain heal would apply an average hps increase from chain heal of 1.5%.

If this is correct then chain heal and spell crit would be more viable in certain circumstances.

One thing i haven't factored in is the effect on GCD, although our totems now have a base GCD of 1sec, with our only other instant cast spells being purge (dispells usually handled by totems), the benefit of reducing GCD is negligable. (at the lower levels of haste)
He lumped the entire amount of the chain heal into one number. There is no additional multiplier from crit on chain heal since he already included the entire amount into one number. If one jump of the chain crits is it not a crit for all 3. I haven't had coffee and can't think how the math 3 independant jumps for crit and chain heal right but seems like it would average out to being the same since while there is a greater chance of one jump critting there is also a greater chance for one jump not to crit.
#672SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3yaya@EU-hyjal
Originally Posted by Vanquish

using the figures you provided(again over simplified)
Actually yes I forgot to mention, the figures 1%haste = 0.5% crit in HPS and 1% crit = 0.5 % HPM increase, are in fact true on average. Which means the figures will be verified over the course of a lot of spell casting.

For the purpose of comparing relative values of stats, this is a correct approach.
#673SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Vanquish
Excellent, thank you all for your replies on this.

It seems crit does have it's benefits, and would be more at home in a heals heavy gear set up, as there is some over time HpM benefit. Haste on the other hand would be more at home in an Mp5 heavy set up, to compenstate for the lack of an HpM benefit.

I think from my point of view the HpS and HpM benefit of crit appeal to me more than the raw HpS increase of haste. I'm not sure it would be worth attempting to balance the two stats, as without reasonably heavy + haste most of the benefit is lost in lag.

So, when i eventually get my hands on the T6 helm, a nice shiny spell crit gem will be going in it
#674SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3chezie
I know that its kind of off topic but, I have a question about Chain Heal. Does it just randomly choose which target to heal or is their some sort of priority over targets with low health and full health? I was just wondering when i saw a shaman in my guild on top of the WWS charts with barely any overhealing and Chain Heal doing 85% of all his heals.
#675SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3vorda
Originally Posted by chezie
I know that its kind of off topic but, I have a question about Chain Heal. Does it just randomly choose which target to heal or is their some sort of priority over targets with low health and full health? I was just wondering when i saw a shaman in my guild on top of the WWS charts with barely any overhealing and Chain Heal doing 85% of all his heals.
Chain heal intelligently chooses targets based on range (duh :p) and missing HP.

The patch they added that AI to chain heal was the patch it got used for more then topping off melees (I was raiding on my shaman back in the day).
#676SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Hodor
Originally Posted by chezie
I know that its kind of off topic but, I have a question about Chain Heal. Does it just randomly choose which target to heal or is their some sort of priority over targets with low health and full health? I was just wondering when i saw a shaman in my guild on top of the WWS charts with barely any overhealing and Chain Heal doing 85% of all his heals.
It chooses as its next target the one that is missing the most HP.

For example:

Person A has 8k out of 10k life. Person B has 10k out of 14k life. Chain heal will choose Person B as its next target.

This has the effect that usually there is only (significant) overheal on the primary target. The more raid-wide damage flies around, the less overhealing we have. And 85% is actually quite low as a heal percentage (at least at a Tier 6 level).


On another note: I just remembered that if Chain Heal jumps back to you on its first jump (the second heal), it will NOT jump to a third target. This means that it is sometimes better to target yourself for the first heal in order to make sure it jumps to two other targets .

Since there is a PTR at the moment, it might be worth a try to report that as a bug (using the PTR tool) - who knows they might fix it (sometime).
#677SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3amroberts59
Chain Heal
I usually run at about 90% of my heals being Chain Heal. Last night in Hyjal, I was at 89% but this is mainly due to trash and healing the tanks/melee. Overheal used to bother me, but I've just come to realize in Hyjal and Black Temple that overheal is just part of being a resto shaman. I actually have some other shamans in my guild that are telling me i'm a terrible healer due to my overheals. But I then state to them, you cast 70 heals on Naj'entus while I cast 220. You go oom with your 70 LHW's and HW's, while i'm still at about 30% mana with my 220 Chain Heals. I may be at 30%+ overheals, but my melee groups never die. My guild is clearing Hyjal and Black Temple on a weekly basis, but we still have some shamans who believe chain heal is the lesser of the resto shamans healing spells.
#678SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3herzausgold
Originally Posted by amroberts59

I can say we have extremely motivated healers that chainpot and whatnot, while most of them are trying to top the healing meters, while doing their assigned job. Due to the good performance we managed to progress faster through SSC/TK than expected, by reducing the number of healers to 7, somethimes 6.

Nonetheless, most of them have 45-50% overheal when tankhealing is important, except the druids which end up on ~30% due to hots not showing in the combat log on a topped target.
I would not worry much about your 30% OH. it is just part of raid healing.

It chooses as its next target the one that is missing the most HP.

For example:

Person A has 8k out of 10k life. Person B has 10k out of 14k life. Chain heal will choose Person B as its next target.

This has the effect that usually there is only (significant) overheal on the primary target. The more raid-wide damage flies around, the less overhealing we have. And 85% is actually quite low as a heal percentage (at least at a Tier 6 level).


On another note: I just remembered that if Chain Heal jumps back to you on its first jump (the second heal), it will NOT jump to a third target. This means that it is sometimes better to target yourself for the first heal in order to make sure it jumps to two other targets .

#681SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Shinwei
Originally Posted by amroberts59
But I then state to them, you cast 70 heals on Naj'entus while I cast 220. You go oom with your 70 LHW's and HW's, while i'm still at about 30% mana with my 220 Chain Heals. I may be at 30%+ overheals, but my melee groups never die.
I think whatever combat log parser you're using is counting each jump of Chain Heal as a "hit". So if you have 220 chain heals showing during Naj'entus you really only casted around 1/3rd of what he report says.

Nevertheless, you are correct in assessing that people not dying has a much greater importance than overheal numbers.
#682SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3amroberts59

I've pointed them to anything that will get their thick-headed attitudes towards chain healing. They're just in the Pre-BC state of mind that overhealing is a bad thing. Overheals in Burning Crusade are just a part of raiding now. With the massive mana pools and mana regen that are available at a tier 6 level it just happens. You don't have to be "smart" with where you place your heals anymore. If you think someone is going to take damage, you heal them, even if you can't step cancel in time it's just a drop out of a large bucket mana-wise.

#684SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Skyhoof
Originally Posted by Hodor
On another note: I just remembered that if Chain Heal jumps back to you on its first jump (the second heal), it will NOT jump to a third target. This means that it is sometimes better to target yourself for the first heal in order to make sure it jumps to two other targets .
Originally Posted by Daidalos
Yes good point about the odd jumps Hodor. I always forget about that until after I see it then remember to start the chain on myself the next time. Might be a nice tip to have in the OP.
Great tip. I've added it to the section that deals with Chain Heal.

I also added the [Redeemer's Alchemist Stone] This trinket ranks right up there with the one Illidan drops. While it theoretically adds 40 mp5, it will actually add 8-16 mp5 if you drink 1-2 mana pots during a 10 minute fight. However, you're getting mana when you need it the most, which really makes it a great trinket. Not to mention the passive 119 +healing.

And I know people are wondering: Should I drop a profession and take Alchemy for the new trinket?

No, you shouldn't drop a profession and take up Alchemy just for this trinket. It's very very good. However, there are some excellent alternatives such as [Tome of Diabolic Remedy] or [Eye of Gruul] that are available even if your guild isn't killing Illidan.

However, there are some situations in which it might be adviseable to make a profession change. For example, you have a gathering profession on your main that can be fulfilled by an alt -- Herbalism, Mining or Skinning. It might make sense for your main to take up Alchemy (or another crafting profession such as Enchanting or Jewelcrafting).

The game is always evolving so I wouldn't base my choice on a profession on a single item.
#685SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3
Edited onPatch 2.3.3		Daidalos
Originally Posted by Skyhoof
And I know people are wondering: Should I drop a profession and take Alchemy for the new trinket?

No, you shouldn't drop a profession and take up Alchemy just for this trinket. It's very very good. However, there are some excellent alternatives such as [Tome of Diabolic Remedy] or [Eye of Gruul] that are available even if your guild isn't killing Illidan.

However, there are some situations in which it might be adviseable to make a profession change. For example, you have a gathering profession on your main that can be fulfilled by an alt -- Herbalism, Mining or Skinning. It might make sense for your main to take up Alchemy (or another crafting profession such as Enchanting or Jewelcrafting).

The game is always evolving so I wouldn't base my choice on a profession on a single item.
Aye. I just dropped herbalism to pick up LW for sunwell. So I'm now LW alchemy but I woudn't really say everyone should do this. Our GM promised to give 1500g to anyone who speccing LW for the good of the guild. Drums are a nice additional boost to your group that gets better the more people in group have it so that you can constantly be rotating drums. I do wish drums of restoration would be stronger though. 600 mana and health back seems rather miniscule for people with 11-12k hp / mana. 600 mana back every 2 mins is only 25 mp5 (as opposed to potting which is about 100 mp5) however if all 5 people in the group pop drums in rotation you can get 5x that which is a nice 125mp5 this is when drums start really being nice. I'll most likely be using drums of battle (haste is decent for a healer as well at least) since I am in the mage group but its nice that there is a healer group friendly dynamic you can stack as well.

I've felt alchemy was the best profession for a healer but I'd stop short of saying its a requirement. I can't say enough how valuable the current alchemist stone was on the those progression nights where mana could mean the difference between a kill and a wipe and the new alchemist stone is just amazing. JC also has some very nice trinkets and of course a profession's value changes everytime a new recipie is introduced. If no further recipies are introduced before Lich King i'd say that alchemy, JC, and LW look to be most beneficial for a healer in sunwell. Engineering has some really nice goggles but if you can get a good equivalent in sunwell from a drop the value of Engineering drops off a bit imo.

#686SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Karede
Originally Posted by Skyhoof
The game is always evolving so I wouldn't base my choice on a profession on a single item.
Yeah, I personally took up alchemy largely for the Alchemist's Stone, but also because I knew that I would be chain chugging mana pots, and it was simply more cost effective to have a potion spec alchemist rather than buying mana pots off of the AH all the time. And at that time, all of our alchemists were either transmute or elixir. So it was useful in that way too. Now with this new trinket, it becomes an even better investment in my opinion.
#687SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Ghando
Nobody in their right mind would claim you NEED the new Alchemist's Stone for top-end healing; I'm sure there will be at least one very appealing healer trinket in Sunwell Plateau, and you can pair it with the Memento of Tyrande for a fantastic combo without switching your profession. However, given that the Redeemer's Stone is a "guaranteed drop" that you'll get without really difficult mats in a profession that's pretty easy to level if you have access to an Herbalist...it makes a lot of sense to go for it. I'm aware that there may be something better down the line, but it's not like Alchemy will ever go out of style.

Glimmering Naaru Sliver
Use: Gain 250 mana each second for 8 seconds. Channeled. (5 min. Cooldown)
Equip: 119 healing.
yeilds 2000mana / 300 = 6.66m/s
6.66m/s * 5s = 33.3mp5

This puts the new alchemist stone pretty even with the the best healing trinket out of sunwell. Alchemist stone returns slightly more if you chain pot at everycool down but considering you don't usually pot until 30-45 s into a fight one could argue it makes them pretty even. My only gripe would be the 8s of channeling required to get all the mana back. if I have 8 s to stand around I might as well pop a dreamless sleep.
Last edited by Daidalos : 03/03/08 at 3:54 PM.

#691SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Skyhoof
Shaman with C# Knowledge
We can't let Elemental shaman have all the good toys.

Rawr is a program originally designed to rate gear, enchants and buffs for feral druids. It's creator is now making the platform available to all classes and specs. It’s designed to fill the role currently filled by spreadsheets but Rawr is easier to use and automatically handles item data.

Console is working on a beta version for Elemental shaman based on Binkenstein’s Shamstats. He has thought about doing a resto version but can’t commit to it until he has a working Elemental model.

So I wanted to find out if we had anyone with C# knowledge lurking in the resto thread. Rawr is written in C#, using .NET Framework 2.0, using Visual Studio 2008. You can find all the details here: Rawr Model Development
#692SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Saberwolf
Nice guide and all but I got a question though. I soloed the game up to 68 and start doind instances. So, my gear sucks. I got 3/5 of my gladiator set, but I want to be PvE Healer. Should I farm that Gladiator set or get a dungeon set like the Tidefury one ?

Thanks.
#693SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Gaise
Originally Posted by Saberwolf
Nice guide and all but I got a question though. I soloed the game up to 68 and start doind instances. So, my gear sucks. I got 3/5 of my gladiator set, but I want to be PvE Healer. Should I farm that Gladiator set or get a dungeon set like the Tidefury one ?

Thanks.
Best to just quote the front page of this guide for an answer, I guess:

1. Which gear is better? X or Y?

For a simple comparison, go to Loot Rank. Enter the stat weights for your level that I give in this post. The only items that it won't rank correctly are trinkets and I have a whole section in this post about healing trinkets.
The commonly used stat weights for resto gear are also posted on the front page of this guide.

With this information, you can work out which works our better for you between the different gear choices you have available to you.
#694SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Zorick
Originally Posted by Saberwolf
Nice guide and all but I got a question though. I soloed the game up to 68 and start doind instances. So, my gear sucks. I got 3/5 of my gladiator set, but I want to be PvE Healer. Should I farm that Gladiator set or get a dungeon set like the Tidefury one ?

Thanks.
For just starting Kara and 5-mans you will be more than okay with using a PVE gemmed gladiator set. Thinking back to when I was first stepping into 25-mans, I was using S1 shoulders and the second-sight helm from Shadowmoon for my healing set.

Although, with the exceptionally good, easy to get badge gear, you should be able to replace your Gladiator gear fairly quickly if you are doing heroics and what not.
#695SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Shiine
Relic Totems
Hi I'm a starting resto shaman running Kara and Gruuls, and I greatly benefited from this thread. I don't know how many times I read this thread over and over. So first of all, Thank you so much!

I have a question and also a correction to make for this thread. They both regard to relic totems.
1. Question:
When you cast Water Shield with [Totem of the Thunderhead] , does the effect last even after you switch your relic totem?

2. Correction:
This macro you gave us is really great.

/Cast Chain Heal
/equip Totem of Healing Rains

I use this macro and variations of this macro for every healing spell because changing relics while casting, in fact, does not activate 1.5 second global cooldown. So canceling a spell to cast another spell within 1.5 second will not endanger us in any way. (Weapons do activate the global cooldown, but relics do not)

Thank you again for this great thread!
#696SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Ceecee
Try casting a chainheal, then interrupt it after 0.5 seconds by moving one step or using another macro with /stopcasting and you will notice the GCD (you wont be able to cast anything for another second). Quite dangerous when you try to abort a heal to throw a NS'd Healwave in emergencies imo. I suggest you try those totem swap macros out for a while, maybe you like it, maybe you don't.
#697SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3vorda
I use this macro and variations of this macro for every healing spell because changing relics while casting, in fact, does not activate 1.5 second global cooldown. So canceling a spell to cast another spell within 1.5 second will not endanger us in any way. (Weapons do activate the global cooldown, but relics do not)
It does, but you have to be in combat for it. Redo your test as stated in the post above (when in combat).

For what it's worth, I use /equip libram macros for all my heals, including FoL, and very rarely run into GC issues.
#698SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3
Edited onPatch 2.3.3		TheSorcerer
I used to use the totem macros, but switched them off for arenas, because there you'd constantly run into the gcd issue (especially if canceling heals to shock). Currently I don't use them in pve anymore either. If I'll use mostly chainheal during a fight I just equip Healing Rains totem otherwise I'll equip Maelstrom totem. If needed I'll switch them manually (eg EoS when running oom in p2).
The benefit of casting 10 Healing Waves for 24 mana less each in a fight is not significant enough to run into gcd troubles in my opinion. Ironically situations where gcd issues could arise due to totem swapping mostly are situations where you'll need to act quick and cannot afford such issues, thus I cancelled using totem swapping macros.

As a side note: to beginning healers I cannot stress enough that a comfortable and good interface is most important to be a good healer. All those totem macros, knowledge of correct downranking and spell canceling, stat ditribution, etc will not help you if you cannot see who will need heal. Learning how to and ensure you actually can see who will get damage before they actually do is a very important step in becoming a good healer. There are alot of good raid frames out there that might fullfill most tasks, but you really should get. grid. fullstop. It might not be as fancy, but it's better.
Last edited by TheSorcerer : 03/06/08 at 8:09 AM.
#699SourcePosted onPatch 2.3.3Daidalos

I used to use the totem macros, but switched them off for arenas, because there you'd constantly run into the gcd issue (especially if canceling heals to shock). Currently I don't use them in pve anymore either. If I'll use mostly chainheal during a fight I just equip Healing Rains totem otherwise I'll equip Maelstrom totem. Ironically situations where gcd issues could arise due to totem swapping mostly are situations where you'll need to act quick and cannot afford such issues, thus I cancelled using totem swapping macros.

As a side note: to beginning healers I cannot stress enough that a comfortable and good interface is most important to be a good healer. All those totem macros, knowledge of correct downranking and spell canceling, stat ditribution, etc will not help you if you cannot see who will need heal. Learning how to and ensure you actually can see who will get damage before they actually do is a very important step in becoming a good healer.
